questions.text: The operation of plication of inferior lid retractors is indicated in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Senile Entropion Senile entropion as a form of spastic entropion of the lower lid , or conversely the commonest form of the spastic entropion is described as occurring in the lower lid of elderly people. It is usually attributed to a spasm of the orbicularis muscle brought on by ocular irritation. The entropion is corrected by two factors The tightening of the orbicularis muscle , which has accumulated at the upper lid margin. The buried suture by supporting the lower half of the tarsus does not allow it to turn outwards and thus keeps it against the globe, restoring to some extent the ori¬ginal snug relationship. The scar tissues formed along the subcutaneous stitch are of further help in correcting the entropion.

Highyeild:

Positioning the sharp posterior lid margin against the cornea is essential for the integrity of the tear film and the health of the ocular surface.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A, C & D . are incorrect

Extraedge:

Rolling inwards of the lid margin are called Entropion and are produced by a disparity in length and tone between the anterior skin muscle and posterior tarso conjunctival laminae of the eyelid.

questions.text: A recurrent chalazion should be subjected to histopathological evaluation to exclude the possibility of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sebaceous gland carcinoma Sebaceous carcinoma is a rare, highly malignant, and potentially lethal tumour of the skin, which most commonly occurs in the eyelid. The neoplasm arises from sebaceous glands , such as those of the meibomian glands in the tarsus, the Zeis glands of the eyelashes, the caruncle, and the skin of the eyebrow. The lesion occurs more often in the upper eyelid, most likely due to the presence of a greater number of meibomian glands (~50 glands in upper eyelids, ~25 in lower) . Sebaceous carcinoma can also occur in other body areas in 25% of cases including other areas of the head and neck and other areas of skin with hair, even genitalia.

Highyeild:

Muir-Torre Syndrome (MTS) is an important consideration when a patient is diagnosed with sebaceous carcinoma . MTS is an autosomal dominant condition of sebaceous tumours associated with gastrointestinal, endometrial, and urologic tumours (without any predisposing factors).

Extraedge:

The sebaceous tumours included in this syndrome are sebaceous adenoma , basal cell epithelioma with sebaceous differentiation, and sebaceous carcinoma .

questions.text: Treatment of ptosis caused by Horner's syndrome is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fasanella Servat operation Oculosympathetic paresis results from an interruption of the sympathetic nerve supply to the eye and is characterized by the classic triad of miosis (ie, constricted pupil), partial ptosis, and loss of hemifacial sweating (ie, anhidrosis), as well as enophthalmos (sinking of the eyeball into the bony cavity that protects the eye). The term Horner syndrome is commonly used in English-speaking countries, whereas the term Bernard-Horner syndrome is common in France.

Highyeild:

Von Passow syndrome is an association of Horner syndrome with iris heterochromia (heterochromia iridis).

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with brief involuntary closing of the eyes which becomes less apparent when attention is diverted elsewhere. Onset was reported as insidious with an insignificant previous history of ocular disorders. What is your initial impression?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Blepharospasm The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Blepharospasm This consists of involuntary, sustained and forcible eyelid closure which may be of two types: Essential blepharospasm, which occurs spontaneously; and Reflex blepharospasm, which may be precipitated by sensory stimuli.

Highyeild:

Essential blepharospasm has an insidious onset between the ages of 45 and 65 years , with brief involuntary closing of the eye affecting one or both eyes and leading to an inability to open the lids. It is less apparent when attention is diverted

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Positioning the sharp posterior lid margin against the cornea is essential for the integrity of the tear film and the health of the ocular surface. Rolling inwards of the lid margin are called Entropion and are produced by a disparity in length and tone between the anterior skin muscle and posterior tarso conjunctival laminae of the eyelid. Option: B. Eversion of the lid margin and eyelashes away from the globe is known as ectropion. In very mild cases, asking the patient to look up will show that the puncta are not opposed to the globe. Over time, as the ectropion progresses to the moderate stage, it will be found that the puncta are not opposed even in primary gaze, and progressively the entire lid margin will fall away from the globe. Option: C. Lagophthalmos is a condition in which there is incomplete closure of the palpebral aperture when an attempt is made to shut the eyes.

Extraedge:

It may be due to contraction of the lids from cicatrization or a congenital deformity , ectropion, paralysis of the orbicularis, proptosis due to exophthalmic goitre, orbital tumour, etc., or due to laxity of the tissues and absence of reflex blinking in people who are extremely ill or moribund.

questions.text: A 9-year-old male was brought in due to constant foreign body sensation and epiphora. On exam, you notice misdirected lashes that are directed backwards. Which of the following statements are incorrect regarding this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Any condition causing Entropion will lead to the condition of this patient

options.label: B
options.text: Recurrent corneal ulcers are eventually produced

options.label: C
options.text: In all cases with recurrences or those occurring in elderly individuals, the lesion should be biopsied to rule out a meibomian cell carcinoma.

options.label: D
options.text: Visual loss may occur in this patient

questions.correct_answer: C. In all cases with recurrences or those occurring in elderly individuals, the lesion should be biopsied to rule out a meibomian cell carcinoma.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In all cases with recurrences or those occurring in elderly individuals, the lesion should be biopsied to rule out a meibomian cell carcinoma. The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of trichiasis . Trichiasis is a misdirection of the cilia so that they are directed backwards and rub against the cornea. The statement in the given option holds true for Chalazion. In all cases of chalazia with recurrences or those occurring in elderly individuals, the lesion should be biopsied to rule out a meibomian cell carcinoma .

Highyeild:

Very hard chalazion are occasionally met with, particularly near the canthi, which may be adenomata of the glands and require Malignant changes occur but are rare.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Any condition causing scarring of the eyelid margin or entropion will cause trichiasis , trachoma and spastic entropion being among the most common. It may also be caused by congenital distichiasis . Option: B. Recurrent erosions, superficial opacities , vascularization of the cornea and frequent, recurrent corneal ulcers are eventually produced. Option: D. Trichiasis may prevent corneal ulcers from healing despite therapy, thereby threatening vision.

Extraedge:

A few of the lashes may be affected or the condition may be due to entropion involving the whole margin of the lid.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female presented with recurrent episodes of irritation, pain, reflex blepharospasm and watering. On the exam, the following findings were noticed. What is the appropriate treatment Epilation Electrolysis Diathermy Cryotherapy Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.correct_answer: D. a, b, c and d
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a, b, c and d The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of trichiasis . Trichiasis is a misdirection of the cilia so that they are directed backwards and rub against the cornea. The symptoms are those of a foreign body continually present in the eye with irritation, pain, conjunctival congestion, reflex blepharospasm and lacrimation.

Highyeild:

Recurrent erosions, superficial opacities, vascularization of the cornea and frequent, recurrent corneal ulcers are eventually produced. Trichiasis may prevent corneal ulcers from healing despite therapy, thereby threatening vision.

Random:

Explanation for all options: - Option: A. Epilation: Isolated misdirected cilia may be removed by epilation which must be repeated every few weeks. Option: B. Electrolysis: Destruction of the hair follicle by diathermy or electrolysis is preferable. The follicles may also be destroyed by cryosurgery and argon laser applications. Cryosurgery may be used to treat segmental trichiasis but can lead to necrosis and depigmentation of the lid. Option: C. Diathermy: In diathermy , a fine needle is inserted into the hair follicle and a current of 30 mA is applied for 10 seconds. It should be remembered that electrolysis is both painful and tedious , but pain may be avoided by injecting a local anaesthetic into the margin of the lid. Option: D. Cryotherapy of the lash root is done after splitting the lid margin at the grey line and placing the cryoprobe on the affected root, followed by a double freeze-thaw cycle at −20 degree Celsius. It is indicated in patients with multiple trichiatic or distichiatic lashes.

Extraedge:

It is commonly due to inflammation such as chronic blepharitis or herpes zoster ophthalmicus, but can also be caused by an injury or by surgery, such as incision and curettage of a chalazion.

questions.text: Match the following conditions with misdirected eyelashes to their respective causes Select the correct answer from the given below ciode:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-C, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b Trichiasis refers to the misdirection of growth from individual follicles, rather than a more extensive inversion of the lid or lid margin. The follicles are at anatomically normal sites. It is commonly due to inflammation such as chronic blepharitis or herpes zoster ophthalmicus, but can also be caused by an injury or by surgery, such as incision and curettage of a chalazion.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Marginal entropion has increasingly been recognized as a very common cause of eyelash misdirection, secondary to subtle cicatricial posterior lamellar shortening that rotates a segment of the lid margin towards the eye. The mucocutaneous junction migrates anteriorly and the posterior lid margin becomes rounded rather than physiologically square. Typically, numerous aligned lashes are involved. Option: C. Congenital distichiasis is a rare condition that occurs when a primary epithelial germ cell destined to differentiate into a meibomian gland develops instead of into a complete pilosebaceous unit. The condition is frequently inherited in an AD manner. The majority of patients also manifest primary lymphoedema of the legs (lymphoedema-distichiasis syndrome) . A partial or complete second row of lashes is seen to emerge at or slightly behind the meibomian gland orifices. The aberrant lashes tend to be thinner and shorter than normal cilia and are often directed posteriorly. Option: D. Acquired distichiasis is caused by metaplasia of the meibomian glands into hair follicles such that a variable number of lashes grow from meibomian gland openings. The most important cause is intense conjunctival inflammation (e.g. chemical injury, Stevens-Johnson syndrome , ocular cicatricial pemphigoid).

Extraedge:

In contrast to congenital distichiasis , the cilia tend to be non-pigmented and stunted and are usually symptomatic.

questions.text: A 78-year-old female presents with epiphora and itchiness. Nerve sensation was intact and tarsal conjunctiva was found to be thickened and keratinized. The exam finding is shown in the image below. There is no prior history of trauma or ocular diseases. Which of the following is not an aetiologic factor?

options.label: D
options.text: Over-riding of the pretarsal by the preseptal orbicularis

questions.correct_answer: D. Over-riding of the pretarsal by the preseptal orbicularis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Over-riding of the pretarsal by the preseptal orbicularis The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of involutional ectropion with keratinization of the marginal conjunctiva . Involutional (age-related) ectropion affects the lower lid of elderly individuals. It causes epiphora (tear overflow) and may exacerbate the ocular surface disease. The red appearance of the exposed conjunctiva is cosmetically poor.

Highyeild:

In long-standing cases the tarsal conjunctiva may become chronically inflamed, thickened and keratinized .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Horizontal lid laxity can be demonstrated by pulling the central part of the lid 8 mm or more from the globe, with a failure to snap back to its normal position on release without the patient first blinking. Option: B. Lateral canthal tendon laxity is characterized by a rounded appearance of the lateral canthus and the ability to pull the lower lid medially more than 2 mm . Option: C. Medial canthal tendon laxity , demonstrated by pulling the lower lid laterally and observing the position of the inferior punctum. If the lid is normal the punctum should not be displaced more than 1-2 mm. If laxity is mild the punctum reaches the limbus and if severe it may reach the pupil.

Extraedge:

Overriding of the pretarsal by the preseptal orbicularis during lid closure tends to move the lower border of the tarsal plate anteriorly , away from the globe and the upper border towards the globe, thus tipping the lid inwards and causing entropion.

questions.text: Match the different types of involutional ectropion to their respective treatment approaches: Select the correct answer from the given below ciode:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-B, 2-C, 3-A. The approach to repair depends on apparent causation and the predominant location of the ectropion. Generalized ectropion is treated with the repair of horizontal lid laxity. This is achieved with a lateral tarsal strip procedure. Eversion of the lid margin and eyelashes away from the globe is known as ectropion.

Highyeild:

In very mild cases , asking the patient to look up will show that the puncta are not opposed to the globe . Option: B. Medial ectropion , if mild, may be treated with a medial conjunctival diamond excision (medial spindle procedure). It is often combined with a tarsal strip or lateral canthal sling. Option: C. Medial canthal tendon laxity , if marked, requires stabilization prior to horizontal shortening to avoid excessive dragging of the punctum laterally.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: B. Medial ectropion , if mild, may be treated with a medial conjunctival diamond excision (medial spindle procedure). It is often combined with a tarsal strip or lateral canthal sling. Option: C. Medial canthal tendon laxity , if marked, requires stabilization prior to horizontal shortening to avoid excessive dragging of the punctum laterally.

Extraedge:

Over time, as the ectropion progresses to the moderate stage, it will be found that the puncta are not opposed even in primary gaze , and progressively the entire lid margin will fall away from the globe.

questions.text: Match the typical features to the respective disorders of anomalies in the position of lid margins or eyelashes Select the correct answer from the given below ciode:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d. Generalized ectropion is treated with the repair of horizontal lid laxity. This is achieved with a lateral tarsal strip procedure. Eversion of the lid margin and eyelashes away from the globe is known as ectropion.

Highyeild:

In very mild cases , asking the patient to look up will show that the puncta are not opposed to the globe .

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Upper eyelid congenital entropion is usually secondary to the mechanical effects of microphthalmos Option: B. Lower eyelid congenital entropion is caused by improper development of the lower lid retractors. Option: C. Overriding of pretarsal orbicularis: Degeneration of palpebral connective tissue separates the orbicularis muscle fibres and thus allows preseptal fibres to override the pretarsal fibres and thus tipping the lid margin inwards. Option: D. Congenital ectropion is very rare but may be seen in Down syndrome and blepharophimosis syndrome.

Extraedge:

Over time, as the ectropion progresses to the moderate stage, it will be found that the puncta are not opposed even in primary gaze , and progressively the entire lid margin will fall away from the globe.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presented with chronic irritation, lacrimation and photophobia. On examination, the lid margin is found inturned. The posterior lid border is inturned up to the intermarginal strip. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Grade II entropion The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Grade II Entropion 2⁰ to senile causes. Symptoms occur due to the rubbing of cilia against the cornea and conjunctiva and are thus similar to These include foreign body sensation, irritation, lacrimation and photophobia

Highyeild:

Depending upon the degree of inturning, it can be divided into three grades . Grade II entropion includes turning up to the intermarginal strip.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Grade I entropion , only the posterior lid border is inrolled Option: C. Grade III entropion , in which the whole lid margin including the anterior border is inturned Option: D. There are only 3 grades according to the severity of involvement.

Extraedge:

Marginal entropion has increasingly been recognized as a very common cause of eyelash misdirection , secondary to subtle cicatricial posterior lamellar shortening that rotates a segment of the lid margin towards the eye.

questions.text: Match the surgical procedures given in the table below with the subtypes of entropion for which they are commonly preferred Select the correct answer from the given below ciode:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d Out rolling or outward turning of the lid margin is called ectropion. Congenital ectropion is very rare but may be seen in Down syndrome and blepharophimosis syndrome. It may occur in both the upper and lower lids and is due to a congenital shortage of the skin.

Highyeild:

Depending upon the degree of out rolling, ectropion can be divided into three grades : Grade I : In it, only punctum is everted. Grade II: Lid margin is everted and palpebral conjunctiva is visible. Grade III: The fornix is also visible.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Congenital entropion may resolve with time without the need for any intervention or may require the excision of a strip of skin and muscle with the plastic reconstruction of the lid crease (Hotz procedure). Option: B. Indications of posterior lamellar graft . Operations include severe entropion with upper eyelid retraction. In this operation, the deficient or keratinized conjunctiva and the scarred and contracted tarsus are replaced by a composite posterior lamellar graft. Tarsus may be replaced by preserved sclera or ear cartilage or hard palate along with conjunctival or mucous membrane graphs. Option: C. Wies operation (Transverse lid split and Everting sutures) is indicated for long-term cure in patients with little horizontal laxity. Option: D. Cicatricial entropion is treated by a plastic operation, which is based on any of the following basic principles: Altering the direction of lashes, or Transplanting the lashes, or Straightening the distorted tarsus. Transposition of tarso conjunctival wedge. (Modified Ketssey's operation) is indicated to treat a moderate amount of cicatricial entropion.

questions.text: A patient with blepharophimosis syndrome presented with epiphora and mild photophobia. On exam, the lid margin is everted and palpebral conjunctiva is visible. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Congenital ectropion, grade II The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Congenital ectropion, grade II. Out rolling or outward turning of the lid margin is called ectropion. Congenital ectropion is very rare but may be seen in Down syndrome and blepharophimosis syndrome. It may occur in both the upper and lower lids and is due to a congenital shortage of the skin.

Highyeild:

Depending upon the degree of out rolling , ectropion can be divided into three grades: Grade I: In it, only punctum is everted. Grade II: Lid margin is everted and palpebral conjunctiva is visible. Grade III: The fornix is also visible.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Grade I ectropion: In it, only punctum is everted. Option: C. Grade I entropion, only the posterior lid border is inrolled Option: D. Grade II entropion includes turning up to the intermarginal strip

Extraedge:

Congenital entropion may resolve with time without the need for any intervention or may require the excision of a strip of skin and muscle with the plastic reconstruction of the lid crease (Hotz procedure).

questions.text: Match the common causative/associated factors of outward turning of the lid margin to the following subtypes Select the correct answer from the given below ciode:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d. Out rolling or outward turning of the lid margin is called ectropion. Congenital ectropion is very rare but may be seen in Down syndrome and blepharophimosis syndrome. It may occur in both the upper and lower lids and is due to a congenital shortage of the skin.

Highyeild:

Depending upon the degree of out rolling, ectropion can be divided into three grades : Grade I : In it, only punctum is everted. Grade II: Lid margin is everted and palpebral conjunctiva is visible. Grade III: The fornix is also visible.

Random:

Explanation for all options: - Option: A. Mechanical ectropion occurs in conditions where either the lower lid is pulled down (as in tumours) or pushed out and down (as in proptosis and marked chemosis of the conjunctiva). Option: B. Congenital ectropion is very rare but may be seen in Down syndrome and blepharophimosis Option: C. Paralytic ectropion mainly occurs in the lower lids and common causes include Bell's palsy, head injury, infections of the middle ear and operations on the parotid gland. Option: D. Involutional ectropion is the commonest variety and involves only the lower lids and occurs due to the following age-related changes: Horizontal laxity of the eyelid, Medial canthal tendon laxity, Lateral canthal tendon laxity, and Disinsertion of lower lid retractors.

questions.text: A 7-year-old male child presents with the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Congenital coloboma The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of Congenital coloboma It is a rare condition characterised by a full-thickness triangular gap in the tissues of the lids. The anomaly usually occurs near the nasal side and involves the upper lid more frequently than the lower lid. Treatment consists of plastic repair of the defect .

Highyeild:

Coloboma affects around 1 out of every 10,000 children born each year.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Epiblepharon refers to a congenital anomaly in which a horizontal fold of tissue rides above the lower eyelid margin. It usually disappears with the growth of the face and needs no surgical correction. Option B: Euryblepharon refers to the unilateral or bilateral horizontal widening of the palpebral fissure. It is usually associated with lateral canthal malposition and lateral ectropion. Option: D. Abnormal drooping of the upper eyelid is called ptosis. Normally, the upper lid covers about the upper one-sixth of the cornea, i.e., about 2 mm. Therefore, in ptosis, it covers more than 2 mm. Congenital ptosis is associated with congenital weakness (maldevelopment) of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS).

Extraedge:

People with colobomas might be more likely to have other issues with their eyes later in life, including: Cataracts Glaucoma Retinal detachment

questions.text: A young patient presents to the ophthalmic outpatient department with gradual blurring of vision in the left eye. Slit lamp examination reveals fine stellate keratatic precipitate full-thickness flare and a typical complicated posterior subcapsular cataract. No posterior synechiae were observed. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Heterochromic Iridocyclitis of Fuchs Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is a unilateral disease Presents with only floaters , other symptoms are absent Heterochromia iridis is due to the loss of iris crypts is the earliest sign results in diffuse iris stromal atrophy causing a moth-eaten appearance leading to hypochromic heterochromia iridis or reverse heterochromia .

Highyeild:

Amsler s sign on gonioscopy Posterior subcapsular cataract Glaucoma Stellate shaped KP Koeppe's nodules No posterior synechiae

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, C & D. are incorrect

Extraedge:

Von Passow syndrome is an association of Horner syndrome with iris heterochromia (heterochromia iridis).
